<head><hi rend="smallcaps">JONATHAN RICHARDSON, CHARLES CHAUNCY, AND<lb/>THE MANUSCRIPTS OF POPE</hi></head><lb/>
<byline><hi rend="italic">by</hi> <name type="pname">John Considine<hi rend="sup">*</hi></name></byline><lb/>
<hi rend="dropcap">A</hi>s for his <hi rend="italic">Essay on Man</hi>’, recalled the man of letters Jonathan Richardson the younger, in a volume of reflections published in&nbsp;1776, five years after his death,<lb/>
I was witness to the whole conduct of it in writing, and actually have his original MSS.<lb/>
for it, from the first scratches of the four books, to the several finished copies, (of his own<lb/>
neat and elegant writing these last) all which, with the MS.&nbsp;of his <hi rend="italic">Essay on Criticism</hi>, and<lb/>
several of his other works, he gave me himself, for the pains I took in collating the whole<lb/>
with its printed editions, at his request, on my having proposed to him the ‘making of an<lb/>
edition of his works in the manner of <hi rend="italic">Boileau</hi>’<hi rend="sup">1</hi>.<lb/>
The literary manuscripts which Pope gave to Richardson ‘include’, as Mar­garet Smith remarks in the <hi rend="italic">Index of English Literary Manuscripts</hi>, ‘some of the most<lb/>
important surviving MSS&nbsp;of Pope’.<hi rend="sup">2</hi> They were, as we shall see, accompanied<lb/>
in Richardson’s library by collated printed editions of Pope and some non-liter­ary manuscripts.<lb/>
Their movements for a century and more after Richardson’s death have been summed up — not quite accurately — by Maynard Mack: they<lb/>
‘made their way, without ever going on public sale, into the collection of Charles Chauncy, and finally, in&nbsp;1887, to the marketplace’,<lb/>
the last point being minimally elaborated on in an endnote which reads ‘See the Sotheby sale catalogue, July&nbsp;1887’.<hi rend="sup">3</hi> Charles Chauncy was<lb/>
a near-contemporary of Richardson the younger’s, a rich English physician and antiquary; the name is also spelt <hi rend="italic">Chauncey</hi>, as in the<lb/>
<hi rend="italic">Oxford&nbsp;DNB</hi> and several of the sources quoted below.<lb/>
<note place="foot"><hi rend="sup">*</hi> I am grateful to Karen Thomson, who helped me to start thinking about this topic, and<lb/>
to James McLaverty, for his valuable comments on a draft.</note><lb/>
<note place="foot"><hi rend="sup">1</hi> Jonathan Richardson, <hi rend="italic">Richardsoniana, or, Occasional Reflections on the Moral Nature of Man</hi> (London: Printed for J. Dodsley, 1776), 264; for Pope and the Richardsons, see William Kurtz Wimsatt, <hi rend="italic">The Portraits of Alexander Pope</hi> (New Haven and London: Yale University Press, 1965), 73–89 and 137–222, esp.&nbsp;142–143; Helene Koon, ‘Pope’s First Editors’, <hi rend="italic">Huntington Library Quarterly</hi> 35.1 (1971), 19–27; and James McLaverty, <hi rend="italic">Pope, Print, and Meaning</hi> (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2001), 212–213; for Pope and Boileau, see McLaverty, <hi rend="italic">op.&nbsp;cit.</hi>, 87–90, 210–214.</note><lb/>
<note place="foot"><hi rend="sup">2</hi> Margaret M. Smith, ‘Alexander Pope’, in eadem and Alexander Lindsay, <hi rend="italic">Index of English Literary Manuscripts</hi>, vol.&nbsp;3, 1700–1800, part&nbsp;3, <hi rend="italic">Alexander Pope–Sir Richard Steele</hi> (London: Mansell, 1992), 1–78 at 2.</note><lb/>
<note place="foot"><hi rend="sup">3</hi> Maynard Mack, <hi rend="italic">Collected in Himself: Essays Critical, Biographical, and Bibliographical on Pope and Some of his Contemporaries</hi> (East Brunswick, NJ: Associated University Presses, 1982), 325, 346 n 24.</note>
